greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) is the smallest number with exactly n divisors such that all its divisors end with the same digit (which is necessarily 1).
comment: As 1 is a divisor for each number, all the divisors must end with 1.
link: David A. Corneth, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..966
Project Euler, Problem 474: Last digits of divisors.
formula: If n is prime p, then a(p) = 11^(p-1) = A001020(p-1).
example: 121 is the smallest number whose 3 divisors (1, 11, 121) end with 1, hence a(3) = 121.
3751 is the smallest number whose 6 divisors (1, 11, 31, 121, 341, 3751) end with 1, hence a(6) = 121.
a(18) = 4767521 = 11^2 * 31^2 * 41 as it has 18 divisors all of which end in 1. - _David A. Corneth_, Nov 09 2020
program: (PARI) a(n) = {my(pr); if(n==1, return(1)); if(isprime(n), return(11^(n-1))); forstep(i = 1, oo, 10, f = factor(i); if(numdiv(f) == n, pr = 1; for(j = 1, #f~, if(f[j, 1]%10 != 1, pr = 0; next(2) ) ) ); if(pr, return(i)); ) } \\ _David A. Corneth_, Nov 09 2020
results.author: _Bernard Schott_, Nov 09 2020
ext: Data corrected by _David A. Corneth_, Nov 09 2020
